Award.AbstractNarration:
Biological systems display heterogeneity at every level. Even cells that are genetically identical and exposed to the same environments can have different chemical composition. The fundamental reason is that molecules bounce around in an unpredictable way, much like dice do when thrown on a table, and react when they randomly collide. This project will describe the randomness mathematically. Specifically, it will explore the general connection between fluctuations and control, that is, how controlling some parts of a system creates heterogeneity in others, much as small variations in the weather must be translated into large variations in the temperature of radiators to keep the room temperature constant. Rather than model specific systems, it will take a more general approach to capture broad principles of complex systems. That makes the results widely applicable in other disciplines - whether in health and medicine, ecology, or infrastructure problems where conceptually similar challenges arise. The project will train students at the interface between scientific disciplines, as well as generate examples and principles that will be useful in undergraduate education.

Stochastic descriptions of cells have historically relied on detailed computer simulations that must guess many of the system details, or simplified toy models that only include a few reactions. This project will instead focus on the derivation of theorems of sufficient generality to hold for large families of processes, to rigorously understand broader design principles of biological systems. Specifically, the project will focus on deriving bounds on variances as a function of other system properties, to show, for example, how selection for maximal anabolic or enzymatic efficiency inevitably leads to large fluctuations. Similarly, the project will derive fluctuation trade-offs showing how suppressing noise in some components inevitably increases fluctuations in others. Mathematically this relies on both Markov and non-Markov processes, information theory, and fluctuation-dissipation relations, to derive statistical moments for open ended families of models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Life in cells is to a large extent governed by chance. Molecules present in low numbers randomly collide and react, creating fluctuating concentrations and variation in the timing of key events. Numerous control circuits exist to suppress, exploit or otherwise shape such fluctuations, but each control system is also fundamentally limited in multiple ways. Not only are there minimal energy requirements, but sometimes optimizing for one property inevitably impacts others, creating hard bounds and trade-offs.

Many such effects have been suggested by simulating several specific systems and parameters, but little is known about broader physical laws or hard bounds on what is possible or not possible. That is particularly problematic when studying cells since mutations and selection could search for complicated mechanisms that break what had appeared to be a general result. We therefore need a type of mathematics that can rigorously handle uncertainty in assumptions, i.e., where we can specify some aspects of a chemical control system and derive general rules for what is possible without specifying other parts. The challenge is that such frameworks need to handle (1) complex reaction networks with arbitrary topology, (2) nonlinear rate functions with unknown parameters where changes in some concentrations can have any type of impact on others, and (3) stochastic reactions where every discrete individual event is probabilistic and the various components only affect reaction probabilities.

In this exceptionally ambitious grant, we set out to build such frameworks and to identify new laws of stochastic chemistry. Initially we identified several broader areas of interest. For example, how does suppressing fluctuations in one component affect fluctuations in other components of the same network? In anabolic reactions where smaller pieces come together to build larger complexes, is there a trade-off between the efficiency of complex formation and fluctuations in the individual components? For the timing of discrete events, how do fluctuations in the number of states impact the precision of time-keeping? Finally, is it possible to sharply change average concentrations in response to some change in a parameter, without simultaneously creating large intrinsic fluctuations in concentrations, as expected near equilibrium from fluctuation-dissipation results?  

In brief this was arguably the most successful grant we had in 20 years, and we could derive broad results that we believe are fundamental to dynamics in cells, addressing every question above, far beyond what we originally thought would be possible. Specifically, we identified new hard bounds on the precision of timing in chemical systems that directly explain why such timing has been hard to achieve in cells, and also identify optimal topologies and rate functions. We demonstrated a kinetic uncertainty principle where suppressing fluctuations in one component inevitably increases fluctuations in another. We expanded the fluctuation dissipation theorem from physics to classes of systems that are far from equilibrium with strong nonlinear effects. We demonstrated hard bounds on efficiency in anabolic systems as a function of the variances in the underlying components. These results also had an immediate impact on our understanding of specific biological systems, as demonstrated in two of the papers that connect the mathematical principles to experimental data (Lord et al, Science, 2019) and (Reuveni et al, Nature, 2017).
